dek: How 390 high school dress codes are still sexualizing their students in 2019.
author: Amber Thomas
assistance: with data collection assistance from Kait Thomas and Anna Houston
preamble: If you aren't currently in high school, it's probably been a while since you've read a student handbook. Over the past few months, my colleagues and I have pored over 420 of them from schools across the US. We focused specifically on the dress code section — a set of policies hotly debated for being racist, sexist, and promoting sexualization. This is a story of why we did this and what we found along the way.
introQuestion: In early 2017, writer Dana Schwartz posed a question to the Twitter-verse: "Ladies, when was the first time you were made to feel embarrassed and sexualized for what you wore?"

introMemory.value: I thought of my earliest memories of this type of behavior — the times when I wasn‚Äôt aiming to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù, but was perceived that way anyway. I remembered the girls stopped outside of our middle school dance because their shoulders and underarms were bare. Being handed a detention slip because a small sliver of my torso was exposed. Like Dana, each of my earliest memories of feeling sexualized came from the adults that were trying to enforce my school‚Äôs dress code.
I like to imagine that this wasn‚Äôt done maliciously. I mean, it‚Äôs not like my school‚Äôs policy literally said anything like this:

convo1ReceivedText: Ladies, your bodies are too sexy and need to be covered up.

introMessage.value: But that doesn‚Äôt mean that I hadn‚Äôt still received that message. Like so much else in life, words can often hold hidden meanings or insinuations.

When dealing with only the written word, humans and computers are both pretty terrible at separating out the text from their underlying meanings. It‚Äôs why many online users have started using the ‚Äú/s‚Äù notation to indicate that their words should be taken sarcastically, not literally.

All of this makes analyzing dress codes a challenge. We can (and did) collect data from hundreds of high schools to learn more about what they prohibit and why these policies exist. Interpreting the hidden messages the policies send, however, is trickier. We‚Äôll rely on research and reports to help add some context to what we found.

bodyIntro.value: Although the name may imply that dress codes are merely involved with regulating the clothes that students may wear, we found that 80% of schools‚Äô policies specifically prohibited certain body parts from being visible. Those phrases often looked something like this:

bodyExample: [Students may not wear] clothing that bares or exposes traditionally private parts of the body including, but not limited to, the stomach, buttocks, back and breasts.

body-examples.text: [Students may not wear] clothing that bares or exposes traditionally private parts of the body including, but not limited to, the stomach, buttocks, back and breasts.
Shirts must cover the midriff and must cover the chest area (cleavage must be covered).

bodyPostExample.value: Policies like these have recently come under scrutiny. According to opponents, at best, by prohibiting certain body parts from being visible, students receive the message that those body parts are bad, should be hidden, or are of importance to others. At worst, some say that dress codes go so far as to turn whole people into a collection of inappropriate body parts to cover.
According to our analysis, these are the body parts that schools think are most in need of covering.

bodyPartTitle: The Body Parts Prohibited in Each School
bodyPostMultiple: You may have begun to notice some trends amongst the dress code policies. These may become clearer if we aggregate the data from all 420 schools in our dataset.
bodyBarTitle: The Most Commonly Banned Visible Body Parts

bodyOutro.value: I won‚Äôt lie, I was expecting something like genitals to be number one here, but only 6 schools (1%) explicitly ban them. Midriffs, on the other hand — the front part of your body between your chest and your waist — is the most banned body part by a long shot. Which raises the question: why?

The stomach and belly button are not inherently sexual body parts. Though, in Western culture, the midriff, and navel in particular, has a long history of being seen as taboo or indecent. Specifically, the female midriff. Women couldn‚Äôt show their belly buttons on television until the 1970‚Äôs or the streets of New York City until 1985. Arguments go on about whether baring the female midriff is fashionable, erotic, or attractive to those looking at her, but always seem to focus on the people that are observing someone else‚Äôs midriff, rather than the person bearing their own.

This practice of commenting on someone else‚Äôs body and imposing sexuality upon them (whether they intended to be ‚Äúsexy‚Äù or not) falls squarely into the American Psychological Association‚Äôs (APA) definition of sexualization. Compounding the issue, some argue, is that by telling and showing students that these body parts are important to others, we are reinforcing the idea that those parts should be important to them too. Unfortunately, studies have shown that when people are consciously thinking about their appearance, they perform worse on various cognitive tasks like math tests and are more likely to experience eating disorders, low self-esteem, and depression.

clothesIntro.value: Beyond hiding specific body parts, dress code policies typically list a number of items that students are not allowed to wear to school. The average school‚Äôs dress code prohibits around 32 things (the maximum was at 97). Here are some snippets of what these policies may look like:

clothes-examples.text: Shorts and skirt length must be as long, or longer than, the longest fingertip. Shorts and skirts that pass this test may still be deemed inappropriate.
Low-cut tops, spaghetti straps, halter tops, backless tops, tube tops, A-shirts (muscle shirts), clothing that allows for bare midriffs, low necklines, and/or short shorts are not allowed.

clothesMid.value: Many school‚Äôs policies range from prohibiting bare feet or hats to spiked jewelry or promotions of alcohol. Let‚Äôs focus specifically on clothing items that are worn on your body.  This includes any form of shirt, pants, shorts, skirts, dresses, and undergarments.

Although these rules are typically written to apply to all students evenly, in practice, many of them affect some students more than others. For instance, although male students are also not allowed to wear halter tops, that fashion item is typically made for and marketed to girls.
Let‚Äôs see which of the banned clothing items are specifically marketed to girls, boys, or students of any gender.

clothesGraphTitle: Percentage of High Schools Which Prohibit Clothing Items

clothingNotesText.value: * the definition of ‚Äúshort‚Äù varies from school to school. The most common lengths for shorts, skirts, and dresses were ‚Äúto the students fingertips‚Äù (46%), ‚Äúlonger than mid-thigh‚Äù (34%), and ‚Äúlonger than the knee‚Äù (8%). Another 34% didn‚Äôt specify a length, just prohibited ‚Äúshort‚Äù items of clothing. ‚ÄúShort‚Äù shirts refers typically to shirts that can‚Äôt be tucked in or touch the top of the pants.

clothesOutro.value: You may have noticed that almost all of these items are likely prohibited because they reveal parts of the body. In fact, there are only 2 (pajamas and unhemmed pants) that seem to be banned from schools for any reason beyond ‚Äúcovering the body‚Äù.

Of the remaining 34 items, 59% are marketed to girls, 35% to any gender, and only 6% marketed to boys. Once again we see that the bodies and clothes that girls are wearing are more highly regulated than other students.
Some people posit that this is because men have fewer clothing options because their shirts, pants, and shorts are all largely the same style.

Girls clothing, on the other hand, has a wide variety of style options, a much smaller proportion of which are allowed in many of the schools we surveyed. In a study of clothes available for girls in online stores, nearly 30% of available clothes were considered sexualized. That is, they drew attention or focus to sexualized body parts (like the midriff and chest we saw in the previous section) or had ‚Äúsexual‚Äù designs or words on them. While I have yet to find a similar analysis for teen girls‚Äô clothing sizes, the researchers noted that ‚Äútween‚Äù stores like Abercrombie Kids, had the highest rates of sexualized clothing at 41%. If you‚Äôre looking for personal anecdotes of frustrated teens and parents who can‚Äôt find clothes to satisfy the dress code requirements, you don‚Äôt have to look far. One mother even snarkily invited the school‚Äôs principal to take her daughter shopping since she had had no luck in finding shorts that were fingertip length and within budget.

wordsTitle: The Words We Tell Our Students

wordsIntro.value: Even after dress codes ban body parts and clothes that expose the body, making it clear that some parts of you should be hidden, the words we use further reinforce this idea. Most dress codes begin with a few sentences informing the reader what a dress code is for and why it exists.  Here are a few examples:

word-examples.text: Bizarre, immodest or revealing clothing demeans the value of the wearer and disrupts the educational atmosphere. It will not be permitted.
The purpose of the Dress Code is to encourage students to focus on the learning process without the distractions of unsuitable dress and grooming.

Students are encouraged to ask themselves the following questions when choosing what to wear to school:
Does my outfit promote modesty and respectability?
Does my choice of clothing make those around me uncomfortable?
Does my clothing expose too much?
The district‚Äôs dress code is established to teach grooming and hygiene, prevent disruption, and minimize safety hazards.

wordsMid.value: Our words matter. Whether intentionally or not, some of these dress codes are literally telling students that their bodies and modes of dress are distractions or linked to their value or self worth. And as we‚Äôve already seen, it is largely the female students that are receiving these messages.
We extracted the most common words used to offer any rationale for the dress code policies. Explore some examples of the most common words and phrases below.

wordsPostExplore.value: Policies using phrases like ‚Äúdistract‚Äù or ‚Äúdisrupt‚Äù are in the vast majority, representing 75% of the schools in our dataset. The phrasing has not gone unnoticed by students. Back in 2014, students began using the hashtag #IAmNotADistraction in retaliation of policies just like these. Afterall, when girls are reprimanded for being ‚Äúdistracting‚Äù they are likely not distracting themselves. The typical argument falls that they are distracting their male classmates and, disturbingly, sometimes adult men.

Some suggest that creating dress codes like the ones we‚Äôve seen sends a complex message to all students. Specifically, it relays to girls that they are responsible for the way that others see them (and continuing that line of logic, what others do to them) and it relays to boys that they are not in control of their own actions and that they can pass judgement on others based on their appearance.

The words used in dress codes are often incredibly vague. What one administrator may deem ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù would be cause for violation through the eyes of another. When it comes to the actual enforcement of these rules, x% of schools specifically state that the final determination in whether or not a student is breaking the dress code will be a subjective one. Those clauses often look like this:

wordsOutro.value: Bringing subjectivity into this makes something tricky even more complicated because it brings along bias. Reports indicate that students that are ‚Äúcurvy‚Äù or ‚Äúbusty‚Äù are reprimanded more than their less-curvy classmates. Similarly, girls of color, whom are stereotypically perceived as ‚Äúhypersexualized‚Äù, ‚Äúprovocative‚Äù, and ‚Äúnot ladylike‚Äù are disproportionately targeted. They are found in violation of their school‚Äôs dress codes more often than their white classmates, even when both were breaking the rules.

methods.value: All school handbooks were chosen for analysis opportunistically as follows: I found a list of thousands of potential public high schools using the National Center for Education Statistic‚Äôs (NCES) search function for public schools. I limited the resulting schools to just those that had a web address listed and then accessed the homepage web content from each site searching for words like ‚Äúhandbook‚Äù, ‚Äúdress code‚Äù, and ‚Äúcode of conduct‚Äù, filtering my list of schools to just those that contain one of the above phrases. Then, I manually visited the resulting (2000+) websites in an attempt to find the dress code. Dress codes were disqualified from analysis if they: had a uniform policy, were not from the 2018-2019 school year, or represented schools that ‚Äúmagnet‚Äù or ‚Äúboarding‚Äù schools (according to the NCES).

Once the list of dress codes was compiled, I and two data assistants (Kaitlyn Thomas and Anna Houston) manually recorded every rule listed in each dress code, the words used in the dress code‚Äôs rationale, as well as any listed sanctions for breaking the dress code.

introLede.value: The words themselves are harmless enough, but they are tinged with culture-specific meaning. In this case, they bring with them an inherent suggestion of sexuality.

Without a knowledge of cultural contexts, computers are often terrible at separating out explicitly written words from their underlying meaning. In text-only environments, humans are bad at this too. That‚Äôs why many online forums have started using the ‚Äú/s‚Äù notation to indicate sarcasm. All of this makes any quantification of words‚Äô implied meaning challenging. That is, adding data to this conversation is difficult.
This is a story about weaving the words written in more than 420 high school dress codes together with research and reports about the implied meanings of the things we find.

The thing is, dress codes are tricky. These rules were written, seemingly, in an attempt to cover up our bodies and prevent them from being sexualized. But their enforcement does just the opposite, turning people into a collection of inappropriate body parts to be covered. These types of policies are in the news constantly as students push back against the antiquated rules. But even with a never-ending list of examples, and research conducted on public schools in California and Washington DC, these issues are still often presented to the public as a series of isolated incidents. I wanted to better understand just how pervasive the sexualization of students is in dress codes, so we analyzed 390 public high school dress codes across the US for the 2018-2019 school year.

explicit-1: In case you haven‚Äôt read one in a while, high school dress codes are typically written as a list of items that students are prohibited from wearing.
explicit-2: When these policies are called ‚Äúsexist‚Äù you may imagine that these policies are explicitly gendered. That is, that the policy is written to only affect one group of students. Here‚Äôs an example:
explicit-3: In this case, male students are being singled out and explicitly prohibited from wearing earrings, a fashion item that female students are still allowed to wear. We found gendered prohibitions like this in 28% of schools. Here are the most common items allowed for some students and prohibited for others.

explicit-4.value: While technically legal, policies like these promote gender stereotypes and can be especially damaging to LGBTQ and non-cisgender students.
But this isn‚Äôt the only way that dress codes target certain types of students.
